node.title: NASA unveils asteroid-fighting spacecraft as it prepares for Armageddon-style mission test
node.description: The spacecraft will be launched later this month on a test mission to determine whether crashing into an asteroid can change its trajectory.Â
node.content:
["NASA has revealed details of how it plans to deliberately crash a spacecraft into an asteroid to see if it will change the asteroid's course.\u00a0\u00a0", "The spacecraft will be launched later this month as part of the\u00a0space agency's first planetary defence test mission\u00a0called the Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART).", "It will\u00a0direct itself at an asteroid while traveling at a speed of about 24,000 kilometres per hour.", "DART, which launches on November 24, will target a double asteroid Didymos and its moon, Dimorphos.", "", "
The spacecraft will be launched\u00a0from the Vandenberg Space Force Base in California.(Supplied: NASA/Johns Hopkins APL/Ed Whitman)
", "Neither asteroid poses a threat to the Earth, the DART team said.", "\"This is a test. We don't want to be in a situation where an asteroid is headed toward Earth and then have to be testing this kind of capability,\"\u00a0Planetary Defense Officer Lindley Johnson told reporters.", "\"We want to know about both how the spacecraft works and what the reaction will be by the asteroid to the impact before we ever get in a situation like that.\"", "DART, which will launch from California's Vandenberg Air Force base, will reach Dimorphos and Didymos late in\u00a02022.", "\"Our team is excited, extremely sharp, and they genuinely want to show that if an asteroid was coming toward Earth, we could prevent a catastrophe,\" said\u00a0DART mission systems engineer Elena Adams.", "", "
It's hoped the impact of the spacecraft will change the course of the asteroid.(Graphic supplied:\u00a0NASA/Johns Hopkins APL)
", "Reuters/ABC"]
